awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Student Produced Audio Narratives (SPAN)
awd_abstract_narration:
The U.S. needs more, and more diverse geoscientists for the workforce, but recruiting new geoscience majors is difficult. This project will test the impact of a simple but potentially effective curricular change in large, introductory courses with a goal of improving non-science major student engagement in STEM by introducing student-produced audio narrative assignments to the curriculum. Student-produced audio narratives (SPAN) are assignments in which students engage with geoscience content by telling a scientific story using simple audio recording and production techniques. The overall goal of using of SPAN in STEM courses is to develop methods that will change the learning environment so that students feel an increased personal connection to STEM, particularly in the geosciences. 

SPAN assignments are ideally suited to the challenges of introductory courses, such as large classes, minimal laboratory materials/access, and limited faculty support, especially in underserved programs. This pedagogical approach has the potential to positively impact students' perceptions of geosciences, and science in general, and to increase their engagement with the learning environment. The research team will develop a collaborative and iterative implementation model with a regional Partner Faculty network and embedded assessment. In the first semester, Partner Faculty (focused in the mid-Atlantic region) receive training on technical and storytelling aspects of audio production and developing audio assignments tailored to their own classes. Partner Faculty will implement the assignments over the next three semesters. This project explores and implements the tool of student audio production, develops an implementation model though a Partner Faculty network, and measures the learning outcomes using mixed methods to research students' perception of and engagement in science. A collaborative regional network of faculty will design and implement student-produced audio narratives in their introductory-level classes, including at two-year community colleges. This project creates and tests flexible, adaptable assignments incorporating student-produced audio narratives. Finally, it researches the impact of student-produced audio narratives on students' perceptions of their learning environment and attitudes toward science using novel educational research methods.

por.por_cntn:
This Level-I Engaged Student Learning (ESL) pilot project examined an important issue in geosciences. The U.S. needs more, and more diverse geoscientists for the STEM workforce, but recruiting new geoscience majors is difficult. Large, introductory courses with lots of non-STEM majors are valuable opportunities for recruiting new geoscience majors. If students have a positive first experience learning about geosciences, it can lead to further interest in the field. However, teaching introductory classes is difficult. Introductory courses often have challenges like large class sizes, minimal laboratory materials/access, and limited faculty support, especially in underserved programs. To reach students in these classes, the approach must be realistic for the instructor as well as effective for the student. Therefore, this NSF grant examined a simple but effective pedagogical change in introductory courses - substituting a Student-Produced Audio Narrative (SPAN) assignment for a standard course assignment. This research created a regional pilot study to examine how SPAN assignments impact student perceptions of their learning environment as well as how faculty responded to including SPAN assignments in their courses. Overall, the results of the pilot study indicate that SPAN assignments are effective at producing positive attitudinal changes in students and can be implemented in a wide variety of introductory geoscience courses. 

SPAN assignments are a novel form of active learning that can be used in introductory courses. In SPAN assignments, a student or group of students is tasked with creating a geoscience narrative in audio form. Students use basic, free audio recording and production techniques. This is a low-cost, easy-to-implement approach that is accessible for many introductory teaching environments. Through this approach, students focus on storytelling rather than on reporting or listing facts.  Students use their creativity to describe a scientific concept in a way that they find interesting, engaging and personally relevant.

To evaluate how SPAN assignments influence introductory students, this ESL Level 1 project formed a regional network of six pilot faculty at six different regional institutions with diverse student populations: City University of New York, Queens, a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) and Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution (AANAPISI), Rutgers University (HSI, AANAPISI), Delaware County Community College (27.9% Black/African American), Penn State Abington (50% minority students), Harrisburg Area Community College (13.3% Hispanic; 8.2% Black/African American), and Albright College (24% Black/African American; 16.1% Hispanic). Using a faculty cohort model, the faculty participants received professional development on SPAN assignments through face-to-face workshops and ongoing mentoring over the course of the project.  Faculty developed their own SPAN assignments, unique to their courses and institutions that integrated with their existing teaching needs.  The pilot faculty, in turn, instructed over 700 student participants enrolled in 25 undergraduate introductory-level geoscience courses over three semesters to complete a SPAN assignment. 

We analyzed the response using a mixed methods approach.  To understand the impact of SPAN assignments of student attitudes, we combined a quantitative validated survey on student perceptions of their learning environment with qualitative interviews about the experience. Students in all three experimental semesters demonstrated statistically significant pretest-posttest improvement in the scales of Personal Relevance, Future Intentions to Study Science, and Innovation. Two of the three experimental groups showed improvement in the Scientific Storytelling scale, and one group showed improvement in the Place-Based Learning scale. In interviews, students revealed that enjoyment, personal connections, and innovation (e.g., surprise at this type of assignment in a science class) were key themes in the student experience, and they felt empowered by the choice involved in the SPAN assignment.  

This NSF-funded research determined that the SPAN pedagogical approach is ideally suited to the challenges of introductory courses (large classes, minimal laboratory materials/access, etc). In addition, SPAN assignments produced positive outcomes across a broad range of institutions (large and small) and different courses, indicating promise for widespread implementation in introductory-level geoscience courses. Another valuable impact was the successful engagement of faculty from smaller institutions who have not had prior opportunities to participate in educational research, and the positive results seen with their students. Ultimately, the research showed that this relatively simple pedagogical change to introductory course assignments can positively impact the way students perceive STEM topics in general, and geosciences specifically, in their own lives. The PI team and faculty participants have disseminated the grant work through two peer-reviewed publications and 20 local-to-national conference presentations.
